pull_request.title: fix(docs): Fix some doc errors that slipped in

commits.message:
docs(tower): Mention how to enable http feature from sentry crate (#622)

It is common to have this integration pulled in via the tower feature
of the sentry crate.  In this case it is convenient to know about the
shortcut of the tower-http feature instead of having to add a direct
dependency to sentry-tower.

docs(tower): Mention how to enable http feature from sentry crate
pull_request.body: It is common to have this integration pulled in via the tower feature of the sentry crate.  In this case it is convenient to know about the shortcut of the tower-http feature instead of having to add a direct dependency to sentry-tower.

comment.body:
well, it looks like the tests were not happy with the way that explicit forceful shutdown and the channel interacted with each other, so I removed that.
The difference to the transport is that the transport can have long running http requests, and you can explicitly flush with a timeout, and then force-shutdown.

pull_request.title: Add experimental metrics implementation
pull_request.body:
This adds:
- A new `metrics` / `statsd` EnvelopeItem
- A new `MetricFlusher` which is implemented similarly to the `Transport` and the `SessionFlusher` and is added to the `Client` as well
- A `cadence` compatible `SentryMetricSink` which is the primary user-facing thing to use
- And a ton of internal types that are mostly adapted from `relay-metrics`

Unfortunately, we can’t use `relay-metrics` directly because of circular imports, but also because `relay-metrics` is lacking a usable aggregator as well as methods to print metrics to the `statsd` compatible output format.

- And a ton of internal types that are mostly adapted from `relay-metrics`

Unfortunately, we can’t use `relay-metrics` directly because of circular imports, but also because `relay-metrics` is lacking a usable aggregator as well as methods to print metrics to the `statsd` compatible output format.

commits.message: remove forced shutdown from metrics aggregator
try to fix flush race on windows

issue.title: Improve the ability to debug sentry integration
issue.body:
I have been trying to integrate sentry tracing with to one of the applications at work and I'm having some issues with it.

When trying to debug it further, I provide these options:

```
            sentry::ClientOptions {
                release: sentry::release_name!(),
                session_mode: sentry::SessionMode::Application,
                debug: true,
                // Fixme: Change to 1% sampling rate at production
                traces_sample_rate: 1.0,
                ..Default::default()
            },
```

And when the debug is `true`, it provides output like this:

```
[sentry] Get response: `{"id":"ae0962de93bb4e4bbafa958fb4737a44"}`
```

Unfortunately it's not very helpful for my case. Is there a way for me to understand what that id is and how to correlate with it ? Probably there is a documentation related to this, but I'm not able to find it in the crate docs or just general searching.

comment.body: I agree that the response itself might not be as useful. At this point the transport is dealing with `Envelope`s and it might be possible to at least debug-print the types of envelope items.

issue.title: feat(metrics): Preliminary work for metrics aggregation
issue.body: This PR is not for merging. It's a draft implementation of metrics aggregation that was not for merging. The actual work is in #618

issue.title: Improve the ability to debug sentry integration
issue.body:
I have been trying to integrate sentry tracing with to one of the applications at work and I'm having some issues with it.

When trying to debug it further, I provide these options:

```
            sentry::ClientOptions {
                release: sentry::release_name!(),
                session_mode: sentry::SessionMode::Application,
                debug: true,
                // Have 1% sampling rate at production
                traces_sample_rate: 1.0,
                ..Default::default()
            },
```

And when the debug is `true`, it provides output like this:

```
[sentry] Get response: `{"id":"ae0962de93bb4e4bbafa958fb4737a44"}`
```

Unfortunately it's not very helpful for my case. Is there a way for me to understand what that id is and how to correlate with it ? Probably there is a documentation related to this, but I'm not able to find it in the crate docs or just general searching.

pull_request.title: Add experimental metrics implementation
pull_request.body:
This adds:
- A new `metrics` / `statsd` EnvelopeItem
- A new `MetricFlusher` which is implemented similarly to the `Transport` and the `SessionFlusher` and is added to the `Client` as well
- A `cadence` compatible `SentryMetricSink` which is the primary user-facing thing to use
- And a ton of internal types that are mostly adapted from `relay-metrics`

Unfortunately, we can’t use `relay-metrics` directly because of circular imports, but also because `relay-metrics` is lacking a usable aggregator as well as methods to print metrics to the `statsd` compatible output format.

comment.body: Ah, I didn't catch that `RecvTimeoutError` has two variants.

comment.body: Thats a good point, though I copied most of this code from the transport that has the same logic. I can’t remember why that was, but also I don’t want to change it too much tbh.

pull_request.body:
This adds:
- A new `metrics` / `statsd` EnvelopeItem
- A new `MetricFlusher` which is implemented similarly to the `Transport` and the `SessionFlusher` and is added to the `Client` as well
- A `cadence` compatible `SentryMetricSink` which is the primary user-facing thing to use
- And a ton of internal types that are mostly adapted from `relay-metrics`

Unfortunately, we can’t use `relay-metrics` directly because of circular imports, but also because `relay-metrics` is lacking a usable aggregator as well as methods to print metrics to the `statsd` compatible output format.

comment.body:
That is what `relay-metrics` uses: https://getsentry.github.io/relay/relay_metrics/type.CounterType.html
So I just stuck with that. Admittedly it does not make as much sense.

- A `cadence` compatible `SentryMetricSink` which is the primary user-facing thing to use

Unfortunately, we can’t use `relay-metrics` directly because of circular imports, but also because `relay-metrics` is lacking a usable aggregator as well as methods to print metrics to the `statsd` compatible output format.
